instrupy.util.SphericalGeometry¶

class instrupy.util.SphericalGeometry(shape=None, cone_angle_vec=None, clock_angle_vec=None, _id=None)[source]¶

Class to handle spherical geometries (spherical polygons and circles) which define an closed angular space of interest.

The spherical geometry is maintained internally via vector of cone and clock angles defined in the SENSOR_BODY_FIXED frame with the Z-axis as the pointing axis. This can be paired with an Orientation object (which describes the orientation of the sensor (hence the SENSOR_BODY_FIXED frame) with respect to a reference frame) to obtain the position of the spherical geometry in any desired reference frame.

Variables

  • shape (str) – Shape of the spherical geometry. Accepted values are “CIRCULAR”, “RECTANGULAR” or “CUSTOM”.

  • cone_angle_vec (list, float) – (deg) Array of cone angles measured from +Z sensor axis (pointing axis). If (\(xP\), \(yP\), \(zP\)) is a unit vector describing a point on unit sphere, then the cone angle for the point is \(\pi/2 - \sin^{-1}zP\).

  • clock_angle_vec (list, float) – (deg) Array of clock angles (right ascensions) measured anti-clockwise from the +X-axis. If (\(xP\), \(yP\), \(zP\)) is a unit vector describing a point on unit sphere, then the clock angle for the point is \(atan2(yP,xP)\).

  • diameter (float) – (deg) Spherical circular (about the sensor Z axis) diameter (only for CIRCULAR shape).

  • angle_height (float) – (deg) Spherical rectangular geometry angular width (about sensor X axis) (only for RECTANGULAR shape). Corresponds to along-track angular width if sensor frame is aligned to NADIR_POINTING frame.

  • angle_width (float) – (deg) Spherical rectangular geometry angular height (about sensor Y axis) (only for RECTANGULAR shape). Corresponds to cross-track angular width if sensor frame is aligned to NADIR_POINTING frame.

Parameters

_id (str) – Unique identifier.

Note

cone_angle_vec[0] ties to clock_angle_vec[0] and so on. The last point in both the vectors should be the same as the first point to ensure FOV closure. Except for the case of CIRCULAR shaped FOV, in which we have only one cone angle (cone_angle_vec[0] = 1/2 diameter) and no corresponding clock angle.
